title: 114_hr4312
content: The Act is titled the "Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Sanctions Implementation and Review Act". The Act titled "Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Sanctions Implementation and Review Act" outlines findings by Congress regarding the IRGC's support for terrorist activities, including training proxy groups, insurgents, and terrorist organizations like Hezbollah and Hamas. Iran, identified as a state sponsor of terrorism, uses the IRGC to fund and carry out acts of terror. The Government of Iran engages in serious human rights violations, with the IRGC playing a significant role in these abuses. The IRGC dominates many sectors of the Iranian economy, controlling billions of dollars in various industries through affiliated firms and front companies. The IRGC controls Iran's economy through affiliated businesses and foundations, enriching its personnel through corruption. It supports Assad's regime in Syria with training, weapons, and funding. The US designated IRGC and Qods Force for proliferation and terrorism concerns. Title III of the Iran Threat Reduction and Syrian Human Rights Act of 2012 imposed secondary sanctions on firms dealing with the IRGC and related entities. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action on Iran's nuclear program did not require the US to lift sanctions on the IRGC. On September 15, 2015, Adam Szubin stated that no sanctions relief would be provided to the IRGC or its affiliates. Strengthening sanctions against the IRGC and its affiliated entities, along with imposing secondary sanctions on firms assisting the IRGC, will help cut off resources for its activities. Modification of sanctions on persons supporting or conducting transactions with Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps or other sanctioned individuals. The Iran Threat Reduction and Syrian Human Rights Act of 2012 is amended to block transactions with foreign persons in the US or under US control. The President can issue licenses for US persons to engage in such transactions. The President shall issue regulations within 90 days to implement sanctions on foreign persons despite any existing sanctions. SEC. 4. REPORT BY COMPTROLLER GENERAL OF THE UNITED STATES. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report identifying foreign persons engaging in activities supporting Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps to the President and congressional committees annually. The Comptroller General of the United States must annually report foreign persons linked to Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps to the President and congressional committees. This includes identifying those on the list of designated nationals and those reported to be affiliated with the IRGC within the past three years. The Comptroller General of the United States will report foreign persons associated with Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps to the President and congressional committees. Sources for the report include credible publications, databases, and information from government agencies, NGOs, and foreign entities. SEC. 5. REVIEW, SANCTIONS, AND REPORT BY PRESIDENT. The President must review foreign persons identified in a report to determine if there is enough evidence to impose sanctions. If there is sufficient evidence, the foreign person will be included on a list of specially designated nationals and sanctions will be imposed. The President will review foreign persons for potential sanctions under the Iran Threat Reduction and Syrian Human Rights Act of 2012. A report with the results of the review and any imposed sanctions will be submitted to congressional committees in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. SEC. 6. SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE FILING REQUIREMENTS. Amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires reporting of foreign persons identified in the Comptroller General's report under the Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Sanctions Implementation and Review Act. Effective 180 days after the amendment for reports filed with the SEC. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires reporting of foreign persons identified in the Comptroller General's report under the Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Sanctions Implementation and Review Act, effective 180 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate.
